thread.title: The $128m mistake Liverpool fans are making
thread.title_full: The $128m mistake Liverpool fans are making

title: The $128m mistake Liverpool fans are making
text:
He loves a goal from long range.Four of Emre Can's six #pl goals have been scored from outside the box. #LIVBUR https://t.co/7O1qPqn85O pic.twitter.com/QhpRXJlREo — Match of the Day (@BBCMOTD) March 12, 2017 
KLOPP DELIGHTED WITH REDS’ ‘FIRST UGLY WIN’ 
Liverpool laboured to the 2-1 win over the Clarets, but that didn’t bother Klopp. 
After being beaten by the Clarets earlier in the season, and falling behind early in this match, the manager was pleased to record a victory. 
“The performance was good enough to win the game, the result is massive,” he told Sky Sports. 
“I thought it was our first ugly game we have won. Usually when we are not good, we lose. We are not used to it yet, so it feels a bit strange.” 'The first ugly game we won' 0:54 
“It was intense and we had to fight. We had a few moments, so I don’t think it was only luck that we scored the equaliser. 
“It was clear we had to do a few things better in the second half, and we did. We were really in the game, we fought, took the battle and I liked that, it’s this kind of game which we haven’t won until now.” 
“The first five minutes of the first half were ok, but the most consistent team in style is Burnley, and they play how they play and are really used to it,” he said. 
“They fight for second balls, they had a better formation, and we couldn’t adapt that quickly. We didn’t find the target often enough and we lost the second ball. So they were always in the game. 
“I am happy about three points, that’s the most important thing.” Liverpool's German manager Jurgen Klopp (R) embraces Liverpool's English midfielder James Milner. Source: AFP 
BURNLEY BETTER THAN AWAY RECORD SUGGESTS 
Klopp was right to praise Burnley’s consistency. 
Despite not having recorded a single away win this season, the Clarets’ last seven defeats have been by a single goal with their opponents including Liverpool, Arsenal, Manchester City and Spurs. 
One of the two away points they’ve recorded was in a draw at Old Trafford. 
But Burnley’s great home form means they’re in 12th place on the ladder with 31 points. Burnley's English striker Ashley Barnes celebrates with teammates after scoring. Source: AFP View All Comments The latest sports news, in your inbox daily. Email
